title: U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin Cuts Price of Park Avenue Duplex
text:
The price of U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin’s Park Avenue duplex was recently trimmed by almost 7%.



Now offered at $27.5 million, this is the second price cut on the five-bedroom, six-and-a-half bathroom residence. It was originally listed for $32 million in September 2018, then dropped to $29.5 million in January. The most recent cut came last Wednesday.



Mr. Mnuchin, 56, bought the 6,500-square-foot apartment in 2000, according to public records. He purchased it from his aunt, Carol Lederman, for $10.5 million, according to a Wall Street Journal article published at the time of the initial listing.



The co-op is located at 740 Park Ave., one of Manhattan’s most notable addresses and the subject of the book “740 Park: The Story of the World’s Richest Apartment Building,” by Michael Gross.

More: Bette Midler Lists Manhattan Penthouse for $50 Million

It was designed by Rosario Candela and built by James T. Lee, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis’s grandfather. Residents have included members of some of the city’s wealthiest families, including the Rockefellers, Vanderbilts, Kochs and Bronfmans, The Wall Street Journal reported.



The residence has a private elevator landing and a gallery with a curved staircase with the original banister. The 800-square-foot living room has a wood-burning fireplace and overlooks Park Avenue, and there’s also a formal dining room, a wood-paneled library with a wet bar and an eat-in kitchen, according to the listing.



Private living space is on the upper floor, including the master suite with walk-in closets, a dressing room, a fireplace and two marble bathrooms. Three more en-suite bedroom and a media room are also on the top floor.



Listing agents Judy Kloner and Carol Lederman of Warburg Realty declined to comment for this article. Mr. Mnuchin did not immediately return request for comment.

From Penta: Rapper Q-Tip’s Contemporary Art Collection on Public Exhibition for First Time

The price cut was first reported by the Real Deal.
